Key Arguments: The bill breaches human rights, specifically freedom of speech and expression.
The legislation lacks a clear definition of what constitutes misleading or deceptive information.
The bill could lead to authoritarian censorship and manipulation.
Charging individuals with penalties for sharing information is seen as outrageous and unconstitutional.
Notable Quotes: This bill breeches the human rights of freedom of speech and expression of all Australians.
We need the primary means of information sharing in our current society to remain relatively censorship free and indeed an open marketplace of ideas.
It is clearly going to create scope for manipulation and control for authoritarian censorship, signally the end of freely sharing ideas online.
